summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan addressing logistical arrangements for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. It confirms the receipt of a sealed letter from a lawyer for an alleged victim regarding trial attendance and outlines COVID-19 protocols for public and victim access, as well as access for the defendant's family.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20-CR-330) for which this order is issued, regarding arrangements for her upcoming trial.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who issued this order regarding trial logistics and access.

persons.name: Wendy Olson
persons.context: Coordinator for the Victim Witness Unit at the U.S. Attorney's Office; her contact information is provided for coordinating alleged victim access to the trial.

persons.name: Joseph Pecorino
persons.context: From the District Executive's Office of the U.S. District Court; his contact information is provided for coordinating public and defendant family member access to the trial.

events.title: Court Order on Trial Access Logistics
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues an order detailing COVID-19 protocols and coordination for public, victim, and defendant family access to the upcoming Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court received a sealed letter from a lawyer for an alleged victim regarding victim attendance at Ghislaine Maxwell's upcoming trial.
The court outlines specific COVID-19 protocols for the trial, including the use of overflow rooms with live feeds to ensure public access.
Access for alleged victims is to be coordinated through the Victim Witness Unit (Wendy Olson) and the District Executive's Office (Joseph Pecorino).
Defense counsel may coordinate access for Ghislaine Maxwell's family members through the District Executive's Office.
The document is a formal court order filed on October 14, 2021, in case 20-CR-330.
